PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is called migration?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_FIRST_OPTION: a. Movement in search of jobs.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_THIRD_OPTION: c. People move to a better neighbourhood.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) all of the above

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: People who move out of their own country or region to settle in another country are known as ______________.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) emigrants

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: India’s partition took place in _____________ .
Which of these things get changed when families move?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) all of these

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who are called refugees?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: There are many factors when people are forced to leave their own country. They are known as refugees

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What are the reasons for migration?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: People migrate to move to their own homes, to move to a better neighbourhood, for less expensive homes, while some have transferable services.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between emigrants and immigrants?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Emigrants are those people who move out of their own country or region to settle in another country. Immigrants are those people who come into a country, of which they are not a native, usually for permanent residence.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How does development cause displacement of refugees?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Some major development activities such as construction of dams, hydropower plants, urbanization, expansion of urban areas and development of transport, cause displacement of refugees.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What does make constant changes as we grow?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) our body

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Everybody in a ______________ has some special qualities.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) family

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who are known as differently-abled people?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) all of these

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Anne Sullivan was ______________ teacher.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) relen's

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How do the adults communicate?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The adults use their hands or facial expressions when they speak.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who are differently-abled people?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Differently abled people are those whose one or more sense organs or body parts do not work too well.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How is everybody unique in a family?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Everybody in a family has some special qualities. This makes 2 Knowing About Ourselves and Others everyone in the family unique.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write about some likes and dislikes of the people.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Some people like spicy food, while some like simple food. Some people like to go out and meet others, while some like to stay at home. Some people like to sleep in their free time while some people like to watch TV in their free time.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Vehicles and machines need ______________ to operate.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) fuels

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Coal, petroleum and natural gas are the examples of ______________ fuels.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) natural

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Oil was thus collected in large ______________pools called oil wells.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) underground

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The coal that we see today, was formed from the remains of ______________ plants.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) dead

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Dene the combustion.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The process by which the fuel is converted into energy is known as combustion.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Why are fossil fuels called non-renewable resources?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Fossil fuels are non-renewable sources because they are available in a limited quantity in nature and cannot be created once finished.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between C.N.G. and L.P.G.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: LPG is liquefied petroleum gas and CNG is compressed natural gas. CNG is a cleaner gas than LPG.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a short note on petroleum.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Petroleum was formed by the decomposition of marine animals and plants which were buried millions of years ago. It is crude or unrefined oil and valuable and expensive resource. It is black in colour in its crude form, so it is also called black gold. There are petroleum reserviors at Mumbai High, Digboi Cambay, Ankleshwar and Sibsagar.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Rice, beans and mangoes grow from ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) seeds

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Peas, French beans and lentils are examples ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) legumes

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Sunflower and soyabeans are ______________plants.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) dicotyledons

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Dandelions have tufts of hair that help them to float in ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) air

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Which of these plants was introduced in India by the British?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) Tea

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Define the term germination.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Germination is the process of changing of a seed into a seedling.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is dispersal of seeds?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The scattering of seeds to far off places is known as dispersal of seeds.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Define the term reproduction? How do plants reproduce?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The process of giving birth to young ones of their own kindis reproduction. Plants reproduce from their seeds, spores and other body parts of the mother plants.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you know about the structure of a seed?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Seeds contain an embryo plant and a food source to enable that embryo to become strong and able to produce its own food through photosynthesis.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the difference between legumes and grasses?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The embryo of grasses contains single cotyledon or seed leaf. They are known as EVS-5 49 monocotyledons. The embryo sits close to the surface of the seed and is often called 'fetus', whereas the embryo of legumes is usually inside the seed and includes two seed leaves. They are known as dicotyledons. They store food in cotyledons.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How can plants reproduce from roots?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Roots help in reproduction. Dahlia, guava and asparagus also reproduce by these roots. These roots give rise to new plants when they get favourable conditions.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ is also a home to millions of plants and animals.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) water

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Rooted-floating plants also ______________ on the surface of water.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) float

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Aquatic animals breathe through ______________.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) lungs

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Birds breathe with the help of ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) lungs

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Define the aquatic plants? Give three examples.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Aquatic plants are those plants which live and grow in water. Three examples of aquatic plants are : Water Hyacinth plant Water Lily Lotus

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between free-floating and submerged plants.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Free floating plants are those plants which freely float on water. They are small in size. 5 Aquatic Plants and Animals They float in water because they are not fixed to the soil. They are very light also. Submerged plants grow under the surface of water. They have roots fixed to the waterbed. They have narrow leaves and spongy stems which enable them to float in water.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How are aquatic animals well-suited to live in water?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Aquatic animals are well suited to live in water as they have special body parts that enable them to survive in water.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a short note on whales and dolphins.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Whales and dolphins have streamlined bodies and fins that help them to swim. They have lungs which help them to breathe. So, they come to the 50 Vedanta Answers Key water surface to breathe in air with the help of flippers and suitable limbs.

PR_CHAPTERS.PR_NAME: The Role of Animals in Our Lives

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: People in mountain areas get milk from ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) yaks

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Wool is obtained from the ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) sheep

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Camels, donkeys and horses are known as beasts of ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) burden

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Illegal killing of animals for their body parts is a punishable ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) crime

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: It is easier for the madaris to catch the baby ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) monkeys

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write five various uses of animals.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Uses of animals are : (i) We obtain milk from cows, buffaloes, goats and sheep. (ii) Hens and ducks lay eggs, which are eaten by many people. (iii) Honey is obtained from the hives of honeybees. (iv) We get wool from sheep. (v) Silk is obtained from the cocoon of silkworm.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Why are animals in danger?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The animals are in danger because human beings are hunting them and destroying their habitat by cutting forests.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is Project Tiger?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The project tiger was launched by the Government of India in 1973 to save tigers, which is an endangered species. Under this project, 27 tiger reserves were set up. Many ntional parks and wildlife sanctuaries were also set up in India.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How can people use animals to earn money?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: There are many people who depend on animals for their livelihood. Madaris move around the streets with their pet monkey or bear and make it dance to entertain groups of people, who, in turn, give money. Snake charmers entertain the public by hypnotising snakes. Mahouts capture young elephants and train them to do their bidding.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ is one of the basic needs for most animals.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) communicate

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A dog’s nose is about a hundred thousand times more sensitive than ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) human beings

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: An ______________ can see a rat on the ground from high up in the sky.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) eagle

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Giraffes twist around when they want to ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) sleep

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Honeybees do special dance step known as ______________ dance to inform other bees where the food is.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) waggle

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the need of sense organs to animals?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: All animals possess sense organs to enable them to know their surroundings by the sense of seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting and touching.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Which animal uses its whiskers to feel the changes in the air?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Cats use their whiskers to feel the changes in the air.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How do horses sleep?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Horses can look their legs so that they can sleep while standing. This allows them to make a quick escape if a predabor comes near

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you know about the sense of sight of birds?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The eyesight of birds is very sharp. They have relatively large eyes. They have excellent vision, which is essential for avoiding collisions in flight or for capturing  fast-moving prey

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How do animals communicate with one another?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Most animals communicate by smell. They release pheromones to send messages to others. Honeybees do special dance step known as 'waggle dance' to inform other bees where the food is ryena makes a mad laughing sound that other hyenas follow while hunting.

PR_CHAPTERS.PR_NAME: Uses of Water in Our Lives

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ is the key source of water on the Earth.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) Rainfall

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The heaviness or lightness of an object is called its ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) density

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Water is often referred to as a universal ______________.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) solvent

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: People keep clean drinking water in ______________pots along the roadside.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) clay

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: About ______________ of the Earth’s surface is covered with water.
What is water? Explain its three forms.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Water is a colourless, Odourless and tasteless liquid. Three forms of water are : solid (ice), liquid (water) and gas (steam).

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Define the underground water.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Some part of rainwater is absorbed by the ground and is stored underground.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is a universal solvent?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Water is a universal solvent as it can dissolve a large number of substances in it.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between soluble and insoluble substances.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: A substance that dissolves in a solvent is called to be soluble. Substances that do not dissolve in water are called to be insoluble.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Define the density of an object.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The heaviness or lightness of an object is known as density.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The salivary glands produce ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) saliva

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: There are mainly ______________ kinds of taste buds.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) four

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The food that we eat everyday is known as a ______________.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) diet

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Beri-Beri disease is caused by the deficiency of ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) vitamin B

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Which of these diseases makes the hemoglobin level low?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) Anaemia

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write about the digestion of food.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The moment food enters the mouth, the work of the digestive system starts. The teeth tear and crush the moistened food into a fine paste until it is good enough to be swallowed. In our mouth, the food we eat, gets mixed with saliva. The enzymes in saliva break down the food into glucose. Glucose is then absorbed and carried to different parts of our body. It gives us energy to do different activities.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Why do we need glucose everyday?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Glucose gives energy to our body. If we remain without food for a long time, the glucose level in the body falls. As a result we might feel sick or weak. People  who do a lot of physical activities need extra glucose regularly

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between Scurvy and Beri-Beri.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Beri Beri is a disease of nerves. It affects our eyes and skin, body growth, and blood and muscles formation. It occurs due to deficiency of vitamin B. Scurvy patients have swollen and bleeding gums. They lose weight and become weak. Their teeth start shaking and become loose. It occurs due to lack of vitamin C.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Describe the eating habits of people of different states.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: In Kashmir, all the dishes are prepared around the main course of rice and saag which is prepared with a green leafy vegetable known as the hak. Punjab, Haryana and Uttar Pradesh show high consumption of chapattis as staple food. Besides chapatis, other baked breads in these regions include tandoori, rumaali and naan. Famous dishes of Kerala are the lamb stew and appams, malabar EVS-5 53 fried prauns, idlis, dosas, etc. sweetened coconut milk and puttu

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What are the different processes of food preservation?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Different processes of food preservation are : (a) Freeing (b) Drying (c) Canning (d) Packing (e) Using Preservatives

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: In India, there are ______________ farmers that grow a small amount of crops, which is consumed by them.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) small

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ farming refers to a method of crops and livestock production.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) organic

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The supply of water to dry lands by various ______________ measures is called irrigation.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) artificial

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The Great Bengal Famine took place in ______________ .
Give difference between subsistence and commercial farmers.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Subsistence farmers grow a small amount of crops, which is consumed by them. They often use bullock carts to cultivate the land with small implements. Commercial farmers grow crops on a huge scale which they sell in the wholesale markets for their earnings.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What problems are faced by farmers in India?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Problems faced by farmers are : (i) Drought is a tough period in the life of every farmer. Inspite of their hard labour, they live a life of extreme poverty. Their crops are at the mercy of rains. (ii) When a farmer falls sick, there are no medical facilities for his treatment. (iii) There are less schools for the education of his children. 10 Food Production and Storage (iv) The mud huts in which he lives, often fall down during rain and many more problems are faced by them.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you mean by Green Revolution in India?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: In 1960s, a renowned scientist Dr. M.S. Swaminathan developed the high yielding varieties of seeds with supreme quality of rice and wheat to feed the growing population of countries like India. This is known as the green Revolution.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is organic farming? Define it.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Organic farming is a method of crops and livestock production. In this method, farmers creake natural fertilisers from rotting vegetables and waste materials in the farm by letting worms grow on them.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A ______________ refers to a place or an area having density of trees and shrubs.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) forest

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Van Mahotsava is celebrated ______________ in India every year.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) July

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Many programmes have also been started to ______________ the forests.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) clean

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Gaura Devi and Sunderlal Bahuguna led the ______________Movement
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) chipko

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ has the largest number of sacred groves.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) Himachal Pradesh

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Define the term ‘forest’.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: A forest refers to a place or an area having a high density of trees and shrubs

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What are the reasons of deforestation?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Reasons of deforestation are : (i) to clear land for farming or for construction of houses, buildings, roads and other structures. (ii) with increase in population, the need for forest products, such as fuel, timber, tamboo, grasses, etc

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write briefly about the Bishnois of Rajasthan.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Bishnoi is a community found in the Westen Thar Desert and northern states of India. They are famous for the protection of Indian antelope. They are very strong lovers of wild animals

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you mean by Chipko Movement?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Chipko Movement began from an incident in a remote village called 'Reni' in Garhwal, high up in the Himalyas in the early 1970's 'Chipko' means 'to embrace'. Gaura Devi, Sunderlal Bahuguna and Chandi Prasad Bhatt led this movement successfully

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What does Forest Conservation Act, 1988 say?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The Forest Conservation Act in 1988 made strict punishment for those who violated the rules Strict measures were taken to regulate the activities of the tribals, prohibition regarding feeling of trees in hilly areas and to stop grazing and to prevent forest fires. People should be made aware of the importance and value of trees and encourage them to plant more trees.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Games keep our body fresh and ______________.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) active

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A lot of people take part in games to relieve them from their ______________ and other stress.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) work related

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: All team members respect and support the ideas and decisions of their _________
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) captain

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Thoda martial arts belongs to ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) Himnchal Pradesh

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The national game of India is ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) hockey

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the importance of games in our life?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Playing games keeps our body fresh and active. It is must for all of us. It teaches us about life. People enjoy playing games. It relieves us from any kind of stress. It keeps our bones and muscles strong. It keeps our body in good shape. We also develop our confidence and excel in every field of life.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between an individual game and a team game?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Individual games can be played alone or individually. Team games are played by a group of people who form a team.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you mean by captain?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Captain is the leader of the team. All team members respect and support the ideas and decisions of the captain.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write the names of two martial arts of India.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Two martial arts of India are Thang-ta and Thoda.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Name any three popular sportspersons of India.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Three famous sports person of India are - Sachin Tendulkar, Saina Nehwal, Major Dhyaanchand.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Why does our breath come out of our mouth as clouds on a cold day?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: On a very cold day, our breath comes out of our mouth as clouds because when the water vapours present in our breath comes in contact with the cold air, it condenses, that is, change from gas to liquid. Tiny droplets of water form a cloud that vanishes quickly.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A work keeps a ______________ role in our life.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) vital

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: If garbage is not disposed properly, there would be mounds of rubbish and ______________ all around.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) filth

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A ______________ is the person who mends our shoes.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) cobbler

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Gandhiji would call sweepers’ work an essential ______________ work.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) social

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A ______________ work requires good education and training.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) mental

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Dene the term dignity of labour.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The respect given to all types of labour is called dignity of labour

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you mean by division of labour?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Various people do various kinds of work inthe society. This is called division of labour.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write three persons who do physical work.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Three persons who do physical work are - mason, potter, farmer

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write three persons who do mental work.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Three persons who do mental work are - teacher, doctor, engineer.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write the role of the sweepers in the society.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: If everyone refuses to do the job of keeping the roads clean or disposing garbage properly. There would be mounds of rubbish and filth everywhere. We need someone who helps us in cleaning our surroundings. Sweepers are the people who keep the roads clean.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: This world consists of living beings and non-living ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) things

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Only green plants can make their ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) food

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Decomposes are microorganisms like ______________ and ______________.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) both

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Insectivorous plants generally grow in areas where the soil lacks nutrients especially ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) nitrogen

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Jackal, vulture and hyena are the examples of ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) scavengers

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Explain the food chain and food web.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: A food chain is a sequence of living beings in which each organism acts as food for the next. This chain tells us who eats whom. Plants need sunlight to grow a grasshopper feeds on grass. It is eaten by a frog. The frog is eaten by snake. This is known as a food chain. Food chains do not occur independently in nature. Many food chains get interlinked because most organisms eat more than one kind of food. Many interlinked food chains form a food web.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Explain photosynthesis.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Photosynthesis is a process in which plants use sunlight, water, minerals and carbon dioxide to make their own food.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who are called heterotrophs?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Heterotrophs are animals that cannot make their own food and are dependent on plants and other animals for their food.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who are called parasites?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Parasites are those plants that are unable to make their own food. They get food from other plants.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How are the scavengers helpful to us?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Scavengers keep the environment clean by eating the flesh of dead animals, e.g. Jackals, culture and hyena.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The early man did not know how to grow ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) food

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Rice, jawar and bajra are grown in ______________ and is a kharif crop.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) summers

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The process of removing weeds is called______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) weeding

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A huge amount of grains are stored in ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) silos

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a short note on the early man.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The early man didn't know how to grow food. He collected fruits and nuts from the trees and killed wild animals for food. Slowly, he came to know that he could plant seeds in the ground to grow different plants for food. In this way, farming began.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Differentiate between Rabi and Kharif crops.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Winter crops are called Rabi croups. Summer crops are called Kharif crops.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the difference between threshing and winnowing?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The process of separating grains from the harvested crop is called threshing. Winnowing is separating husk from the seeds by dropping them from a height.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How do farmers protect their crops?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Famrers protect their crops from pests and insects. Pesticides are sprayed by the farmers on the crops. Fences and boundary walls are raised to protect the fields from stray animals.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The ______________ keeps us safe from heat, cold and rain.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) shelter

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: We need a ______________ to build our house.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) mason

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: In hilly and mountain areas, houses have ______________ roofs.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) sloping

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ houses are built with bricks, stones and cement.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) Pucca

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: A colony of ants of social insects is called an ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) anthill

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What is the need of shelters?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Shelter is needed to keep ourselves safe from heat, cold and rain. It guards us and our belongings.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Which types of houses are found in hilly areas?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: In hilly areas, houses are made of wood. They usually have sloping roofs, as such roofs do not allow rainwater and snow to collect and make the houses cold and damp. Many houses in hilly areas have fireplaces.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What materials are used in constructing a kutcha house?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Kutcha houses are made of mud, straw, palm leaves, tin or asbestos sheets are used for the roofs.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you know about stilt houses?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: People living in flood-prone areas make their houses on raised platforms and poles known as stilts. People use a ladder to enter their stilt houses.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: How does economic status of the people decide the type of house they make?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Houses vary in structure and design according to economic status or income of a person. People build their houses depending upon the amount of money they can spend on its construction.

PR_CHAPTERS.PR_NAME: The Story of Adventure and Sports

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who is fond of doing adventurous activities?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) people

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: There are ______________ mountaineering institutes in India.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) two

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Santosh Yadav scaled the Mount Everest ______________ .
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) twice

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: On 3 April, 1984. ______________ became the first Indian to go into space.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) Rakesh Sharma

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Sunita Williams another ______________ astronaut who has gone into space.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) Kalpana Chawla

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Why do people like adventures?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Man is fond of doing adventurous activities, which are exciting, unusual and daring. For these activities, they travel to high mountains, distant lands, cross the rough seas and discover dangerous jungles.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Name two Indian women mountaineers who climbed Mount Everest.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Two Indian women mountaineers who climbed Mount Everest are — Bachendri Pal and Snatosh Yadav

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who was Santosh Yadav? Write few sentences about her.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Santosh Yadav is an Indian mountaineer. She is the first woman to successfully climb Mount Everest. She climbed the peak first in May 1992 and then again in May 1993.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you mean by heavenly bodies?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: All the objects which we see in the sky are known as heavenly bodies.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Name some artificial satellites launched into space by India.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Some artificial satellites launched in space by India are 60 Vedanta Answers Key - Aryabhatta, Bhaskara-1, Rohini, APPLE, Insat-1 A and Insat-3E.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Which is a unique country in the whole world?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) India

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The magnificent Taj Mahal stands at the bank of ______________ river.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) Yamuna

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The Red Fort monument was built by ______________ in Delhi.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (a) Shah Jahan

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: The ______________ also undertakes the repair and maintenance of the monuments.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) ASI

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a brief note on India Gate.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: India Gate was built to pay homage to the soldiers who lost their lives during the first world war. The names of the soldiers who laid down their lives are inscribed on the walls of the gate. It is located at Rajpath in New Delhi. It was designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: What do you know about the Sun Temple?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Sun temple is located at konark in Odisha. It was built by the Ganga King Narsimha Deva-1 in the 13th century. It displays the chariot of the sun God pulled by seven carved horses standing for seven days of the week.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a short paragraph on ASI.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: The Government of India has established the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) to protect and preserve our historical monuments. Damaging these monuments is a punishable offence.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Who built the Taj Mahal in Agra (U.P.)?
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Emperor Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal in Agra.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Man is a ______________ being.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (c) social

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: ______________ are huge revolving storms.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (d) cyclones

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Tsunami is a ______________word which means harbour waves.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: (b) Japanese

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Dene natural calamities.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Natural calamities are sudden changes in nature, which cause great damage and destruction, e.g. earthquake, drought, floods etc.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Explain any two natural disasters.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: Floods - A flood takes place when rivers overflow due to excessive rains. Water from river flows onto land and submerges the land all around. People lose their shelters and belongings. Farmers often lose their crops during floods and it leads to shortage of food.  Tsunami - Tsunamis are huge waves that occurs due to undersea earthquakes or volcanic eruptions. The waves move at a very high speed and crush all objects in their path.

PR_QUESTIONS.PR_QUESTION: Write a short note on the rst aid.
PR_QUESTIONS.PR_ANSWER: In times of natural disasters and accidents, emergency treatment is provided to the victims before the arrival of the doctor or before the victim is taken to a hospital. Such immediate treatment is known as first aid. It is good to know the basic first aid rules as timely first aid can save a person's life. The three rules a first-aider should keep in mind : stay calm, act fast and try and arrange for a doctor.
